By far the cleanest, most well balanced IPA I have tried.  Not too heavy and complimented by a citrus aroma.  Not overly hoppy but remains full of flavor.  The body is solid throughout.  Overall one of my top 5 beers.  Try it!

Tap @ O¬íBrien¬ís.  Pours clear orange-gold with a spongey white head.  Great floral hoppy aroma with lemon and oranges.  Clean, bold hop taste throughout.  Good amount of grapefruit with tangerine, pine without resiny stickiness, and maybe a little pepper.  Bittersweet malt in the finish without being overbearing.  It has the hop bite and taste of an Imperial, but the body of a regualr IPA.  Excellent.
on tap-pours a white head and yellow/gold color.  Aroma is citrus lemon-hops (amarillo).  Taste is citrus lemon-hops (Amarillo), faint medium malt.  OK carbonation.

On tap @ the Stone World Bistro. Pours a clear deep gold with thin bright white head. The aroma is a hit of grapefruit citrus hops mixed with a backbone of sweet maltiness. I love the way these flavors come together as noted in the first sip. The taste is crisp with semi bitter grapefruit hops and more like orange juice. The malts take a back seat to the hops but make a notable appearance bringing the bitter grapefruit citrus hoppiness closer to more like sweet orange juice. Very nice IPA.

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2008 Mmmmmm. yummy.  Tried from cask at Ballast Point¬ís 11th anniversary celebration. Nice creamy 1 finger microbubble head that quickly fades to nothing (very cask like).  Pale yellow-orange color.  Nice medium hoppy aroma after head has faded.  Medium grapefruit hop bitterness.  Kind of easy to drink.  Becomes more watery after a few sips. 8,3,7,3,16:3.7
   Tried again at Churchills with deftim 13 and Ivan 3/6/08.  Wow!  Super duper easy to drink.  Much easier to drink than the younger and elder I had tonight.  I have to bump the rating way up.  I have spoken!

UPDATED: APR 6, 2008 rerate: 6Apr2008 - bottle, shared by steiny
updated reating to 4.0 fm 3.8

-------& tap at ballast point¬ís anniv party

clear golden, very hoppy, almost like hop juice. Very much a great example of a San Diego IPA

Name: Sculpin
Date: 11/30/2006
Mode: Draft
Source: OLBrien¬ís

hazy dark yellow, thin fine white head, lots of lace, sweet pine aroma with a hint of citrus, creamy body, lots of tempered hop flavor, light bitterness, 

Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 12/20
Rating: 3.2/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: *4
Cask/Draft @ Hamiltons. One of my favorite IPA¬ís. Dank, sticky, piney, citrusy, skunky.  A Healthy mouthfeel and dangerously drinkable.

UPDATED: DEC 24, 2010 5 ounce sample tasted at Bistro¬ís IPA fest.  Very pleasant floral, hempy, orangey, tangerine hop aroma.  Light pine aromas also burst through.  Extremely aromatic and totally quaffable.  Transparent golden body with frothy off-yellow head that is relatively perseverant.  Wow.  Lots of hempy, resiny flavors to start.  Becomes nice and malty and quite chewy in the middle.  Finishes orangey, bitter, juicy, and wonderfully hoppy.  Great shit.  The appearance could be a little darker, but that¬ís nit-picking.-----RE-RATE- ounce bottle from Nugget in Roseville, CA.  The aroma on this is so full of mango and apricot.  I can¬ít believe I didn¬ít detect that in my initial rating.  I guess that¬ís what happens when you rate at festivals.  Nice floral hints are also there.  Still very quaffable.  The color is still light, and I certainly don¬ít change my stance there.  Again, the flavor has a ton of apricot to start along with more mango in the middle.  Nice amount of hoppiness with enough malt to balance it.  Great mouthfeel.  Awesome stuff.

Draft at O¬íBrien¬ís.  Lots of citrus and apricot fruit aromas off this light coppery brew wtih a really nice white head.  Flavors were similar with more on the citrus side.  Grapefruit turned to pine somewhat as it warmed.  Sweet fruits with a nice malty backbone.  Pretty full mouth feel.  Very tasty.

Clear, strongly-hued sunshine yellow. Very sharp, dank, resiny aroma. Tangerine, orange zest, basil (?!) - all come through in very modular, defined aroma. Thinnish, elegant but dusty maltiness, anchored by rich notes of mango, tangerine and cantaloupe. Creamy, judiciously carbonated finish.

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2013 Giant vanilla, oak, bourbon aroma, but a wild sour funky tropical fruit flavor.  Giant contrast between aroma and taste, which can be fun!  Yeah, there¬ís hops but this mofo be wild and funky, monky mamma boongie boomie yaaah...!  Yummm!!! On tap at O¬íBriens...good thou wild tastin¬í ayieeeee!!!   :)

Re-rate May 2013: Pours gold from 22 oz bottle.  Aroma of straw hops, grarefruit, sweet malts.  Flavors of big grapefruit rind, cream of tartar bitterness, pepper.  Overall big and bold with big astringency.

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2008 On tap at the Ballast Point brewery, and updated rating from the new bottle version. I am super stoked to see them bottling this great IPA now! Very clear gold with minimal white head that laces nicely. Tap version has a more sturdy appearance. Fantastic floral aroma seeping with hops, it makes my mouth water! Grapefruit, pine needles and orange rind in the aroma as well. Citrus and resiny hops are all over the flavor, balanced extremely well with the biscuity malt undertones. Finishes with long lasting bitterness and notes of peppery ginger spice and rye. Crisp and easy drinking. Awesome West-Coast IPA, one of my favorites of all to boot!

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2008 Aroma is pine sour hoppiness and a sweet vanilla kind of thing. Pours orange - clear. Flavor is mostly pine. Some nice balanced malt blend with the hops and give it a kind of funky flavor. Like sweat socks or something, but not in a bad way really. I also got a little bit of graininess and some caramel malt. Pretty good. At this time during the night I was also pretty fucked up after many big beers.

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2010 On tap @ the Liars¬í Club - Pours a clear golden color with a one finger thick off white head.  Light lacing.  Aroma is pine, citrus, and floral hops.  Flavor is big citrus (oranges) and pine hops with a touch of malt sweetness.  A smooth, medium body beer.  Very nice.

What can I say?  It¬ís Ballast Point, it¬ís an IPA, It¬ís really good.   This town is full of IPA¬ís and this is one of the finest.   Wish BP would bottle this as I like it a tad bit better than Big Eye.
Golden appearance with good white head.Mellow hop aromas. Smooth pleasant IPA. Not too complex or of great depth but enjoyable.
Tasted at Ballast Point.  Light orange color with a fizzy white head.  Good hoppy aroma of pine and citrus.  Very good piney hop taste transitioning to a smooth sweet caramel flavor.

Cask Pull at the PP Real Ale Fest.  Mostly transparent, gentle golden color with an even layer of white soapy head.  Lots of grapefruit and piney hop resins in the nose, creating the initial impression of a big hop monster.  Some light lemony and gentle bready malts back it up some, along with a touch of tropical pineapple spiciness.  Light bodied, mild carbonation.  A bit thinner and less bold than expected, especially considering the nose.  The malt character doesn¬ít seem to stand up to the hop promise too well, leaving behind an herbal crispness in the wake of a bland, grainy cracker-ish malt base.  Perhaps the cask accentuates some of the malt weaknesses or fails to highlight some of the sharp hop characters without the prickling carbonation - these are the thoughts I¬ím left pondering.  Not a bad beer by any means, but I just feel it would be a better cask beer with some more malt complexity.  Finish is dry, clean, and refreshing with a lingering herbal piney hop smack.

Fresh from the brewery. It¬ís a heavy looking brass color with a stiff layer of white head. The initial aroma is pure citrus and hop but a more detailed scent of grapefruit and fresh pine will shine through. The flavor is a strong delivery of citrus and piney hops with just the lightest dabble of grainy malt. This ipa sure does pack a punch which makes me wonder what the alcohol percent is. Also, I didn¬ít think this Sculpin IPA was very far off from Ballast Point¬ís el Dorado double IPA. I think the logo of this sculpin ipa was real cool too.

On tap at the Linkery, Sweet and bitter  with lots of citrus and slight pine. It has a caramel/honey backbone that comes with a hearty dose of malts to balance the big hop kick.  Very clean and fresh, its actually between a double and a regular IPA. Very tasty a fruity finish.

UPDATED: MAY 5, 2008 Bottle sampled on 5/5/08: Pours a transparent orange bronze with a stringy-lacing white head.  Aroma of fresh resiny grapefruity hops and a nice, pale malty sweetness.
Starts with good fullness and sweet caramel flavor with a crisp, citrusy flavor and bittering hop balance toward a refreshing bittersweet finish.  A very nice and drinkable IPA.

Sampled on cask at O¬íBriens on 11/30/06: Pours a clear hazy golden bronze with a well-lacing white head.  Aroma of sweet pale malt with lots of fresh grapefruity hops.  Body starts with a nice, full pale and toasty caramel malty sweetness along with lots of fresh floral piny hops toward a crisp, clean, very drinkable finish.  A nice IPA.

UPDATED: MAR 17, 2008 This stuff is awesome.  A pretty under the radar IPA in SD from what I can see.  It comes and goes - when it¬ís here, try and snatch a pint of it.  Very sharp and dry finish, great pine taste, very crisp.  Leaves you wanting the next sip.   A must try - usually always is at the brewery to taste

Got it on tap at the Brewery.  
In the past year or two I feel I have been hit over the head w/ 100+ ibu beers.  OK, we get it.  But this grapefruit bomb scales back a little (but not too much) to give me a beer that is a little more manageable than a 10% abv hangover-in-a-bottle.   This is REALLY good beer.  Great flavor!

Amazing, the smell of hops knocks you off your feet.  Couldnt believe it when I took a wiff.  My friend got a growler filled with this and gave me some.  Truly a great beer.  Nice and bitter, but not to bitter, hoppy taste and aroma really make this a great beer.
user_location: New York City, New York, USA

text: UPDATED: MAY 11, 2007 Holy mother of god! Had it on draft at Ballast Point Brewery. This one caught my attention big time! I am now an avid IPA fan...thank you Sculpin an Ballast Point. Very citrusy, excellent aroma and excellent taste. Very balanced beer, bitter yet fruity, taste like a combo of mangos and banannas. Very bitter begining but smooth fruity finish....mmmmmm excellent especially for a 7.0% ABV!! Wish they bottled it or at least brewed it more often, sucks when you want a growler fill but they are still fermenting it.

Crazy delicious.  I like my big IPA¬ís to pucker me up and say "Damn, man!".  This does that to me.  Like freshly squeezed hops and hemp, this is a fresh tasting, big time IPA.  One of my favorites from Ballast Point.
Cask:  Hazy copper with a thin off-white head.  Grapefruit and sweet malty aroma.  Malt dominates the flavor with a ctirus end.  Long dry citrus rind bitter finish.  Smooth medium bodied mouthfeel.

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2009 Rating #1 Tap @ Bistro¬ís 9th Annual IPA Festival 8/¬í12/06 (6 3 6 3 14).  Golden color with a light laced white head.  Smooth, grassy malts with a bitter finish.  Some citrus and grapefruit flavors.  Rating #2 Bottle (7 3 7 3 17).  A light golden color with a white head.  Grassy, hoppy, and pine in the aroma.  Smooth and delightfully bitter.  Light fruits and citrus finish.

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2008 Serious need of a re-rate as the first time I rated this it came right after a pint of Elder so this seemed like crap.  Bomber from the Homebrewmart brewery.  Pours much yellower than I expected with a big 3 finger creamy tan head.  Nose is sweet, grassy and hoppy.  Taste is sweet and hoppy with a very piney grassy feeling, a different but big and good IPA.
Had on tap.  Fairly minimal carbonation and lacing.  Amber-colored, hoppy, but not as strong as I¬íd expected based on its billing as a "Double IPA".  Not really anything special, but a good IPA.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2006 Draft: Peach in color with a yellow cast. Stiff and fluffy white foam clings with each sip. Delicate aroma of grassy hops, honeysuckle, tangerine, and lime. Hint of doughy yeast. Carbonation is airy and slightly chalky. Dustily crackery malt dryness neutralizes the initial burst of juicy peach and orangey hops. Notes of popcorn exude as the huskiness/graininess and doughy yeast steadily grow and overshadow the vibrant hops. Flash of peachy acidity refreshes, though it hampers the body. Clean but understated grassy bitterness tickles the palate, but the crackery malt persists. Finishes dully bitter and dryly chalky, but persistently crunchy with malt, as the blandness continues with merely a hint of tangy tangerine. Has a decent aroma, but it could stand to be less doughy. As far as flavor and texture go, it¬ís far too grainy and there¬ís nowhere near enough hop flavor or bitterness to combat it. Pretty simple and boring.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text:
On tap at Mountain Sun¬ís durring their Hop Havrest Month.  

This is a great IPA with all of the charachteristics I like.  Great citrus aroma, ton¬ís of hop flavor and a nice bitter finish that keeps the taste lingering.  Ballast Point has really improved their beers over the years.

@ the homebrew store - Straight clear gold, thin white creamy head.  Nose was just freakin loaded with pine, pine needle, pine resin, pine everything!  Oh yeah, just a hint of grapefruit I suppose.  Deep bitter flavor from start to finish.  Medium bodied, soft carbonation, super hoppy finish.  Any sign of sweet malt would have upped the score even more, but I personally always dig a good hop bomb...

This ale is super good hoppy the inital smell is earthy and intense with a very smooth finish a masterpiece how this ale is not at the top of ballast¬ís list I have no idea. You dont like this you dont like money or sex or fresh fish!!!!!!
Tap at the brewery¬ís 10th anniversary celebration. Citrus and grassy hops aroma, flavors follow with grapefruit and good balance of malt backbone. Very nice IPA.

On tap @ brewery.  Clear, honey, small head, no lace.  Medium body, light carbonation, and lightly dry.  Nothing special about this brew.  Citrus and fruit on the aroma as well as honey.  Flavor is mostly grapefruit rind, with honey, floral-honey-comb.  Kind of typical, but good.

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2008 On tap @ the Linda Vista brewery.  I was really diggin this IPA.  Tastes like the little brother of the Dorado double.  Very nice hoppy aroma with some citrus fruits and a bit of grass.  A nice slightly sweet and  smooth finish.......bottle this!!....hahahaha
On tap. Clear golden in colour with a small head. Hoppy and spicy with notes of pine and flowers. Quite bitter, a bit sweet with a dry aftertaste.
Tap O¬íBrien¬ís. Dark golden color in the glass. Piney and citric hoppy aroma. Crisp hoppy flavor up front. Slightly sweet grapefruit finish.

Tasted at the 9th Annual Bistro IPA Festival (2006). This IPA pours alight gold color. Small sized white foamy head. Aroma is fruity, citrusy and piney. A medium IPA. Malts are fruity and sweet. Hops are grapefruity and floral. Lots of orange and citrus flavors. Medium to low bitterness IPA. Nice balance. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter
Draft. Rich amber beer with an off-white head. Apricot/summer fruit and pine aroma. Resiny/fruity (summer, some citrus) flavor with some sweet malt backing. Big resiny hop finish that lingers.

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2011 5 oz taster at the new Scripps Ranch Brewery: Light amber/golden color with a moderate white head. Aroma is citrus and lightly piny. Flavor starts lightly fruity sweet then come the hops; grapefruit, a little pine and a subtle dry orange rind finish. Balance is definitely on the bitter side, but well done. Medium bodied and smooth with a grapefruit after burp. Also got to meet Jack White (owner/brewer) and Yuseff Cherney (head brewer) who may have sold Tom Nickel his first home brew kit. 10/21/11: My go-to-beer at Point Loma Seafoods.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2010 Poured a dark golden color with a medium sized, off white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of more resiny pine tropical fruits, citrus fruits, caramel malts, and floral hops.  Taste of toffee malts, citrus fruits, light malts, grapefruit, and a dry bitter light alcohol finish.

Draft, Liars Club. Straw yellow with a small but sturdy head. Just a whole bunch of grapefruit and zest, mango and pineapple. Taste is dry and tart with a stinging hop bitterness. The rating can¬ít be complete without noting the piney resin.

Draft at O¬íBriens: Light refreshing pommelo nose, brightly hoppy with caramel and alcohol. Hop monster, light sweetness and moderate bitterness. Good with light musky notes. Good and piney. Yet another hop monster here at O¬íbriens and it¬ís just as good. I can hop myself out here very quickly.
golden light amber hue with aromas of pine, fresh hops, and light floral finish.  Medium bodied with flavors of pine, citrus, flower petals and a light dry finish.

The aroma had big grapefruits, and oranges w/ slight pine notes.  The beer poured a yellow color w/ gold highlights; slight head and thin lacing.  The flavor had grapefruits, oranges, pine and a very slight hint of flowers.  The mouthfeel was light bodied and crisp, really good carbonation.

Clear gold color with a small white head.  Simcoe hop aromatics, grapefruit and floral.  Simcoe and other Cascade family hops in the flavor, very fruity.  Fades to a mild bitterness in the finish with some astringency.  Mouthfeel is medium, slightly sticky over time.

22-Aug-05 (Draft: Ballast Point Brewing Co. in San Diego, CA) Even with this tiny sample glass that Ballast Point uses, lots of grapefruit is blasting my nostrils, and the flavor is strong grapefruit too, but not overly bitter.  Nice pale malt body is somewhat sweet and provides a soft-spoken base for the hops to work off.  With the eight (or so) hops used in this IPA, it has a complex hoppiness, and that complexity is plainly illustrated when this beer is compared side-by-side with Big Eye IPA.  In addition to grapefruit, the bright hops flavors take on an herbal and tea aspects as well, something I don¬ít get with the Big Eye.  And Big Eye is a much maltier and balanced IPA than North Star, which shows more fruitiness and orange citrus.  Yellow in color, fully clear, with an off-white head.  I definitely prefer this to Big Eye, but apparently North Star will be draft only, and will not be a regular offering.28-Aug-05 (Draft: Liars¬í Club in San Diego, CA) Okay, I can actually sample this beer in a REAL glass.  And wow, this is one of the best smelling IPAs I¬íve ever experienced.  Orange citrus, pine and fresh passion fruit like you wouldn¬ít believe, but you¬íve had to have eaten fresh passion fruit out of the shell.  The flavor is similar, tons of passion fruit and pine and citrus.  Moderately bitter and hoppy, but the malt is light and barely perceptible.  Medium bodied, clean and crisp from start to finish.  Medium gold color.  The off-white head pours to half-an-inch in height, settles to a rim, and leaves minimal lacing.

On draft at brewery. This is a special brew that may appear again in the future - let¬ís keep our fingers crossed!  Pours clear dark golden color with a creamy white head that left good lacing.  Aroma is all hops, very crisp, citrus, pine and herby notes.  Flavor is sweet (like lemonade is sweet) but dominated by the tangy, tart hops, grapefruit, pine, grass and subtle earthy notes as well.  Leaves the mouth with a wonderful tingly, pucker.  Medium body and smooth carbonation.  Very nice IPA, at 7.5% abv and 70 IBU¬ís this is bordering on a DIPA.

Pours with an orange-amber body topped by a medium thick head with a good amount of lacing.  It¬ís slightly sweet and hoppy with a nice pine note and a slight citrus note.  The finish is nice and hoppy.  Medium bodied, smooth and very drinkable with a dry finish.
